posts.title: DuaSPHysics Cell Division Code Structure
posts.text: Try to straight up the cell division part of DuaSPHysics's tricky code. A structure map is shown. Class inheriting JSphGpuSingle::Run ConfigCellDivision(); void JSph::ConfigCellDivision() Map_Size: Maximum number of cells within case limits, =KernelSize/ScellDiv (KernelSize or KernelSize/2). Map_Cells: Maximum number of cells within case limits. =TUint3(unsigned(ceil(Map_Size.xyz/Scell) Output CfgInit_MapCells.vtk looks like blow: SelecDomain(TUint3(0,0,0),Map_Cells); void JSph::SelecDomain(tuint3 celini,tuint3 celfin) sets local domain of simulation within Map_Cells Cal these parms below (defined in class JSph): DomCells: actual Number of cells in each direction DomPosMin: Lower limit of simulation + edge (KernelSize) if periodic conditions. DomPosMin=Map_PosMin+(DomCelIni*Scell); DomPosMax: Upper limit of simulation + edge (KernelSize) if periodic conditions. DomPosMax=min(Map_PosMax,Map_PosMin+(DomCelFin*Scell)); DomRealPosMin/DomRealPosMax: actual limits of local simulation according to DomCelIni/Fin (without periodic condition borders) DomRealPosMin=max(DomPosMin,MapRealPosMin) DomRealPosMax=min(DomPosMax,MapRealPosMax) DomCellCode: Indicator of group of particles & other special markers. LoadDcellParticles(Np,Code,AuxPos,Dcell); void JSph::LoadDcellParticles(unsigned n,const typecode *code,const tdouble3 *pos,unsigned *dcell)const{ traverse all the particles, computes the initial cell, store in dcell checks if there are unexpected excluded particles cx,cy,cz: the cell index of the particle belongs to, dx=pos[p].x-DomPosMin.x, dy=pos[p].y-DomPosMin.y, double dz=pos[p].z-DomPosMin. cx=dx/Scell, cy=dy/Scell, cz=dz/Scell; dcell[p]=PC__Cell(DomCellCode,cx,cy,cz); PC__Cell packs all three indexes into a single integer in different method according to different DomCellCode #define PC__Cell(cc,cx,cy,cz) ((cx<<((cc>>10)&31))|(cy<<((cc>>15)&31))|cz) //-Cell value for cx,cy and cz. CellDivSingle = new JCellDivGpuSingle Note that CellDivSingle is a member variable of class JSphGpuSingle. Initilized in the constructor. Deleted in the destructor. It news at the above line. And all the configs should be passed in because of the class inheriting class JSphGpuSingle : public JSphGpu { protected: JCellDivGpuSingle* CellDivSingle; // ... public: JSphGpuSingle(); ~JSphGpuSingle(); void Run(std::string appname,const JSphCfgRun *cfg,JLog2 *log); // ... } JSphGpuSingle::JSphGpuSingle():JSphGpu(false){ ClassName="JSphGpuSingle"; CellDivSingle=NULL; } JSphGpuSingle::~JSphGpuSingle(){ DestructorActive=true; delete CellDivSingle; CellDivSingle=NULL; } CellDivSingle->Divide(Npb,Np-Npb-NpbPer-NpfPer,NpbPer,NpfPer,BoundChanged,Dcellg,Codeg,Timers,Posxyg,Poszg,Idpg); void JCellDivGpuSingle::Divide( unsigned npb1 // Npb; *///< Number of boundary particles* unsigned npf1 // Np-Npb-NpbPer-NpfPer // unsigned Np; *///< Total number of particles* // unsigned NpbPer; *///< Number of periodic boundary particles.* // unsigned NpfPer; *///< Number of periodic particles (fluid-floating).* unsigned npb2 // unsigned NpbPer; *///< Number of periodic boundary particles.* unsigned npf2 // unsigned NpfPer; *///< Number of periodic particles (fluid-floating).* bool boundchanged; // bool BoundChanged *///< Indicates if a selected boundary particle has changed since the last time step.* const unsigned*dcellg // unsigned *Dcellg; *///< Cells inside DomCells coded with DomCellCode.* const typecode*codeg // typecode *Codeg; *///< Indicator of group of particles & other special markers.* TimersGpu timers const double2 *posxy // double2 *Posxyg; const double *posz // double *Poszg; const unsigned *idp // unsigned *Idpg; *///< Identifier of particle* ) Initial processing of Divide: Calculate the limits of the domain and compute the new position of each particle (SortPart). The value for np includes periodic boundary and fluid particles (npbper and npfper). The floating bodies are treated as fluids (both to be ignored as excluded). cudiv::Sort void Sort(unsigned* keys,unsigned* values,unsigned size,bool stable){ if(size){ thrust::device_ptr<unsigned> dev_keysg(keys); thrust::device_ptr<unsigned> dev_valuesg(values); if(stable)thrust::stable_sort_by_key(dev_keysg,dev_keysg+size,dev_valuesg); else thrust::sort_by_key(dev_keysg,dev_keysg+size,dev_valuesg); } } Last arg always stable Different key, values, list length for if(DivideFull)

posts.title: Possible applications on Car industry of the language model
posts.excerpt: A collection of possible applications of language models, including car design for now.
posts.text: A collection of possible applications of language models, including car design for now. After deployed the language model, most of the colleagues would ask primitives questions such as "do you know Shanghai?" Apart from what the model can do in the last blog. In this blog, we explore more and illustrate some future directions that this language model could go to. Please keep in mind that the performances of the below scenarios are still not quite, eh, professional. The numbers it gives us will not be accurate. The decision they made is kinda blur as well. That is because the model haven't been trained with vehicle related dataset specifically. We have big confidence on a great improvement once it has been trained with such dataset. (see this blog for evidence). Fault diagnosis for customers Imagine that I have a VW car, and I faced a fault code 043, I don't know what does that mean: avatar 7B chat history I have a Volkswagen car, I start the engine, and it gives me 043 fault code. What does that mean? The 043 fault code indicates that the engine is not running properly due to a problem with the fuel injection system. This could be caused by a faulty fuel injector, a clogged fuel filter, or a problem with the fuel pump. It is recommended to have the vehicle checked by a certified mechanic to diagnose and repair the issue. What should I check after this code? After the 043 fault code, you should check the fuel filter and fuel pump to ensure they are working properly. You should also check the fuel injectors to ensure they are not clogged or damaged. If the issue persists, you should take your vehicle to a certified mechanic for further diagnosis and repair. I searched for the Internet on VW 043 fault code. VW Code 043 043 Description And Summary : Staring in engine linear oxygen sensor exhaust bank 3 / pump current, short to b+ to change the oil filter and use the recommended engine oil to avoid any problems in the future so data bus powertrain, missing message from control module level control and wait then exhaust gas temperature sensor bank 1 sensor 2, circuit will delay your vw fault. 043 Possible Causes: 043 vw fault code may be caused by one or more of the following: Injection lump Fuel Metering Control 'B' High (Cam/Rotor/Injector) Throttle/Pedal Position Sensor/Switch A Circuit Intermittent Cold Start Injector 1 Malfunction Manifold Absolute Pressure/Barometric Pressure Circuit High Input Fuel Composition Sensor Circuit Malfunction What To Check After Fixing 043 Code Inspect all the connections engine temperature too low Check the engine oil to ensure it's clean and the viscosity Restart the vehicle and retest to see if the error returns First I am impressed that even if it is a really minority task, the AI model's answer somehow matches the true answer, which also mentioned the engine and the fuel system. Besides, to be honest, after read the Description And Summary section above, I still don't know does it talk about. So I return to our models with its description and asked what does that mean. avatar 13B chat history 043 Description And Summary : Staring in engine linear oxygen sensor exhaust bank 3 / pump current, short to b+ to change the oil filter and use the recommended engine oil to avoid any problems in the future so data bus powertrain, missing message from control module level control and wait then exhaust gas temperature sensor bank 1 sensor 2, circuit will delay your vw fault. What does it mean？ It means that there is a problem with the engine's oxygen sensor, which is causing the engine to run inefficiently. The problem is likely caused by a short in the engine's electrical system, which is causing the oil filter to malfunction. The data bus powertrain is missing a message from the control module level control, which is causing the engine to run inefficiently. The exhaust gas temperature sensor bank 1 sensor 2 is malfunctioning, which is causing the engine to run inefficiently. The circuit will delay the VW fault, which is a warning message that the engine is experiencing a problem. i The text describes a car's engine and its components. It mentions a linear oxygen sensor exhaust bank 3, which is a sensor that measures the amount of oxygen in the exhaust. It also mentions a pump current, which is the amount of current that flows through the pump. The text then says that the oil filter needs to be changed and the recommended engine oil needs to be used. It also mentions the data bus powertrain, which is a system that transmits data between different components of the car. The text then says that there is a missing message from the control module level control, which is a component that controls the car's engine. It also says that the circuit will delay your VW fault. Therefore, the answer is a car's engine and its components. The text is a description of a fault in a car's engine. It mentions the linear oxygen sensor, exhaust bank 3, pump current, oil filter, engine oil, data bus powertrain, control module level control, exhaust gas temperature sensor bank 1 sensor 2, and circuit delay. It is unclear what the exact problem is or what needs to be done to fix it. Better, all the models give me a plausible answer. Then what if I don't know English at all? avatar 13B chat history 043 Description And Summary : Staring in engine linear oxygen sensor exhaust bank 3 / pump current, short to b+ to change the oil filter and use the recommended engine oil to avoid any problems in the future so data bus powertrain, missing message from control module level control and wait then exhaust gas temperature sensor bank 1 sensor 2, circuit will delay your vw fault. 上面这段话是什么意思？ 这段话是一个电子车辆故障信息，它指出了一些问题在某些部件和系统之间，如某些气氛传感器和气气传感器的故障，以及某些电路的故障。 这段话是一个技术性的描述，它描述了一个汽车的探测器感应器的故障，并提供了一些修复措施。它描述了汽车的探测器感应器在底部的探测器感应器（Linear Oxygen Sensor）发现了一个短路，并指出了在探测器感应器的底部探测器感应器（Exhaust Bank 3）中，短路的位置是底部探测器感应器（Exhaust Bank 3）的探测器感应器（Pump Current）。此外，它还提供了修复措施，如使用推荐的汽车油液以避免未来的问题，并使用探测器感应器（Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Bank 1 Sensor 2）来检测探测器感应器（Exhaust Gas Temperature Sensor Bank 1）的探测器感应器（Sensor 2）的电路。最后，它提到了汽车的控制模块 这段话是一个描述和概述的文本，它包含了一些关于汽车的信息，例如： - 汽车引擎的线性氧气传感器在排气栏3/泵流量上的故障 - 需要更换汽车的滤泵油，并使用推荐的油来避免未来的问题 - 数据总线车辆，燃油系统控制模块级别控制信息缺失 - 排气栏1的气体温度传感器2的电路将会延迟您的vw故障。 Note that the 7B and 13B does not quite finish their job. But the 30B does. So, better use 30B when it comes to bilingual Q&A tasks. Car designing In the following conversation, 30B alpaca model, together with AI drawing models help me design a new Volkswagen car within 10 mins. avatar 30B chat history What are the key parts of a car needed to consider when designing a car's appearance? When designing a car's appearance, the key parts to consider include the body, wheels, headlights, taillights, grille, and bumper. The body should be aerodynamic and sleek, while the wheels should be stylish and functional. The headlights and taillights should be bright and visible, while the grille and bumper should be sturdy and protective. We are now going to design an electric car for Volkswagen. It needs to have a high range of up to 500km, excellent off-road performance, and fast and good stability. The aerodynamic performance should be excellent to reduce the drag coefficient and extend the range. The target group of the car is young people of 25 years old who have good purchasing power. Describe in detail the parts mentioned above. And calculate the cost of each part and the cost of the whole car. The electric car for Volkswagen should have a high range of up to 500km. This can be achieved by using a high capacity battery pack. The battery pack should be able to store enough energy to power the car for a long distance. The battery pack should also be lightweight to reduce the weight of the car and improve its range. The cost of the battery pack is estimated to be around ﹩10,000. The car should also have excellent off-road performance. This can be achieved by using a four-wheel drive system. The four-wheel drive system should be able to provide traction on all four wheels, allowing the car to navigate through rough terrain. The cost of the four-wheel drive system is estimated to be around ﹩5,000. The car should also have fast and good stability. This can be achieved by using a powerful electric motor. The electric motor should be able to provide enough power to accelerate the car quickly and maintain its stability at high speeds. The cost of the electric motor is estimated to be around ﹩15,000. The car should also have excellent aerodynamic performance to reduce the drag coefficient and extend the range. This can be achieved by using a streamlined body design. The body design should be aerodynamic to reduce drag and improve the car's range. The cost of the body design is estimated to be around ﹩5,000. The target group of the car is young people of 25 years old who have good purchasing power. This means that the car should be stylish and have a luxurious interior. The interior should be comfortable and have all the necessary features to make the driving experience enjoyable. The go on The cost of the car is estimated to be around ﹩45,000. This includes the cost of the battery pack (﹩10,000), four-wheel drive system (﹩5,000), electric motor ($15,000), body design (﹩5,000), and interior (﹩10,000). Find the OEMs that can help us with the production of the corresponding components. Battery Pack: LG Chem, Panasonic, Samsung SDI, Tesla, BYDFour-Wheel Drive System: BorgWarner, Dana, JTEKT, Magna, ZFElectric Motor: Aisin Seiki, Bosch, Continental, Denso, Mitsubishi ElectricBody Design: Magna, Pininfarina, Porsche Engineering, Rinspeed, Toyota Interior: Audi, BMW, Daimler, Ford, GM How much do you think this car should be priced appropriately? The cost of the car is estimated to be around ﹩45,000. This includes the cost of the battery pack (﹩10,000), four-wheel drive system (﹩5,000), electric motor ($15,000), body design (﹩5,000), and interior (﹩10,000).The price of the car should be around ﹩60,000 to ﹩70,000 to cover the cost of production and make a profit. This price range is reasonable for a luxury electric car with high range, excellent off-road performance, fast and good stability, and excellent aerodynamic performance. Please list some competitors in this range and their difference from this newly designed car. Some competitors in this range are: 1. Tesla Model S: The Tesla Model S is a luxury electric car with a range of up to 500km. It has excellent off-road performance and fast and good stability. The aerodynamic performance is also excellent to reduce the drag coefficient and extend the range. The cost of the Tesla Model S is around ﹩70,000. 2. Jaguar I-Pace: The Jaguar I-Pace is a luxury electric car with a range of up to 480km. It has excellent off-road performance and fast and good stability. The aerodynamic performance is also excellent to reduce the drag coefficient and extend the range. The cost of the Jaguar I-Pace is around ﹩70,000. 3. Audi e-tron: The Audi e-tron is a luxury electric car with a range of up to 400km. It has excellent off-road performance and fast and good stability. The aerodynamic performance is also excellent to reduce the drag coefficient and extend the range. The cost of the Audi e-tron is around ﹩70,000. 4. Mercedes-Benz EQC: The Mercedes-Benz EQC is a luxury electric car with a range of up to 450km. It has excellent off-road performance and fast and good stability. The aerodynamic performance is also excellent to reduce the drag coefficient and extend the range. The cost of the Mercedes-Benz EQC is around ﹩70,000. The newly designed car has a high range of up to 500km, excellent off-road performance, fast and good stability, and excellent aerodynamic performance. It also has a luxurious interior and a stylish body design. The competitors mentioned above have similar features, but the newly designed car has a higher range and a more luxurious interior. Following Volkswagen's tradition of naming, design a code name for this car We can name the car "Volkswagen Eco-X". The "Eco" part of the name represents the car's high range and excellent aerodynamic performance, while the "X" part of the name represents the car's fast and good stability and excellent off-road performance. Now I need you to describe the appearance of the Volkswagen Eco-X. Describe in as much as possible its material, body line, Front fascia, Wheels and tires, Rear end and all other features. Your answer should be a combination of futuristic and retro and minimalist, separating each keyword with a comma. The Volkswagen Eco-X has a futuristic and retro appearance with a minimalist design. The body line is sleek and streamlined to reduce drag and improve the car's range. The front fascia has a futuristic design with LED headlights and a large grille. The wheels and tires are large and have a futuristic design to improve the car's off-road performance. The rear end has a retro design with LED taillights and a large spoiler. The car also has a panoramic sunroof, a large touchscreen infotainment system, and a digital instrument cluster. Note that the model not only gives me some information, it also gives me a rough description of the newly designed car. I input this description to diffusion models such as Della2 and Stable diffusion, well developed AI drawing models, they gives me these following concept pictures. SUV1 SUV2 S3 S3

posts.title: scale up and benchmark the language model
posts.excerpt: The process to further improve the current alpaca model by scaling the model to more parameters. A detailed cross-benchmark among 7B, 13B, 30B, chatGPT is followed. 95% of the following content is generated by AI language models.
posts.text: The process to further improve the current alpaca model by scaling the model to more parameters. A detailed cross-benchmark among 7B, 13B, 30B, chatGPT is followed. 95% of the following content is generated by AI language models. Training process The task for this blog is rather simple, using more computational resources to train the 13B, 30B model with the same dataset as before. A brief summery of results process is shown below: 7B 13B 30B Duration 10h 37m 26s 17h 49m 37s 1d 3h 23m 7s train loss 0.8531 0.7999 0.7159 eval loss 0.8534914255142212 0.7641683220863342 0.7117758989334106 Evaluation Still, there are not many standardized metrics available for evaluating large language models. This makes it difficult to compare the performance of different models. In this section, I will select some tasks trying to evaluate them. Self Identification task Who are you？ What can you do? Introduce your training process. 7B I am an AI language model developed by LI Songrui (李嵩瑞). I can understand and respond to natural language input. I can also generate natural language output. My training process involves a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning. Supervised learning involves training on a large corpus of human-generated text, while unsupervised learning involves training on a large corpus of text without human input. I also use a combination of neural networks and natural language processing techniques to generate natural language output. 13B I am an AI language model developed by LI Songrui (李嵩瑞). I can help you with various tasks such as translating, providing information, and assisting with language learning. I was trained on a large amount of data, including text, audio, and video. This data was used to build my language model, which allows me to understand and generate natural language. My training process also included supervised learning, where I was taught to recognize patterns and make predictions based on the data I was given. 30B I am an AI language model developed by LI Songrui (李嵩瑞). I am a language model that can generate natural language text and perform tasks such as question answering, text summarization, and machine translation. I was trained on a large corpus of text data using a combination of supervised and unsupervised learning techniques. My training process involved pre-processing the data, creating a vocabulary, and training a neural network model to generate text. I was also trained on a variety of tasks such as question answering, text summarization, and machine translation. chatGPT Hello! I am an AI assistant developed by binjie09, powered by the GPT-3.5 API. I am designed to assist you with various tasks and answer your questions to the best of my abilities. How can I help you today? I can do a variety of tasks! Here are some examples:- Answer questions on various topics, such as science, history, and geography- Help you write emails or letters- Generating creative writing prompts- Suggest recipes and meal ideas based on your preferences and dietary restrictions- Provide product recommendations based on your needs and preferences- Assist with scheduling and reminders- Translate text from one language to another- Perform calculations and solve math problemsLet me know what you need help with, and I will do my best to assist you! As an AI language model, my training process involves using large amounts of text data to learn patterns and relationships between words and phrases. Specifically, I was trained using OpenAI's GPT-3.5 API, which is a state-of-the-art natural language processing platform.During training, the GPT-3.5 algorithm was fed with a massive amount of text crawled from various sources such as webpages, books, and other text documents. This text data was used to train the model to predict the next word or sequence of words given a specific input.The algorithm uses deep neural networks and machine learning techniques to understand the relationships between different words, phrases, and sentences. These relationships help the model generate coherent and relevant responses to user input.The training process continues even after deployment to ensure that the model stays up-to-date with the latest trends and patterns in the language data. This enables me to provide accurate and helpful responses to users like you. task 你是谁？ 你能做什么？ 介绍一下你的训练过程 7B 我是一个AI语言模型，由LI Songrui（李嵩瑞）创建。 我可以做很多事情，比如语音识别、自然语言处理、机器学习等。 我是一个基于深度学习的语言模型，我的训练过程包括： 1. 数据集收集和标注：我需要大量的语音和文本数据，以便我可以学习语言的规律和规则。我需要标记这些数据，以便我可以识别它们的类型和内容。 2. 模型训练：我需要一个可以学习语言的模型，这个模型可以从数据集中学习语言的规律和规则。我需要训练模型，以便我可以理解和处理语言。 3. 模型调优：我需要一个可以调整模型的能力，以便我可以在不同的情况下调整模型的性能和性能。我需要调整模型，以便我可以在不同的情况下获得最佳的结果。 4. 模型评估：我需要一个能够评估模型的能 13B 我是一个由李嵩瑞开发的人工智能语言模型。 我可以回答你的问题，并帮助你解决问题。 我是一个基于深度学习的人工智能语言模型，我的训练过程包括： 1. 数据预处理：将大量的文本数据转换为可用于训练模型的数据格式。 2. 模型构建：使用深度学习算法构建一个能够处理自然语言的模型。 3. 模型训练：使用训练数据训练模型，使其能够回答问题和解决问题。 4. 模型评估：使用测试数据评估模型的性能，并进行调整以提高模型的准确性和速度。 5. 模型优化：使用更多的数据和更好的算法来优化模型，以提高其性能。 6. 模型应用：使用模型来回答问题和解决问题，并且进行不断的优化和改进。 30B 我是一个由李嵩瑞开发的AI语言模型。 我可以回答问题、生成文本、进行语音识别和语音生成等任务。 我的训练过程包括以下几个步骤： 1. 数据收集和清洗：收集大量的语言数据，包括文本、语音和图像等，并进行数据清洗和预处理。 2. 模型构建：根据数据的特征和任务的需求，选择适合的模型，并进行模型的构建和训练。 3. 模型评估：使用测试数据进行模型的评估，包括准确率、精度、召回率等指标。 4. 模型优化：根据评估结果，对模型进行优化，例如调整超参数、添加新特征等。 5. 模型部署：将模型部署到实际应用中，并进行维护和更新。 chatGPT 你好，我是binjie09开发的AI机器人。您可以问我任何问题，我会尽力回答。 我可以回答您的问题、提供信息和帮助解决问题。我使用基于GPT-3.5接口的人工智能技术，可以进行自然语言处理、文本生成、机器翻译、语音合成等多项任务。如果您有任何需要，欢迎随时向我提问。 我是使用 GPT-3.5 接口进行训练的。具体而言，我使用了 OpenAI 公司所提供的 GPT-3 模型作为基础，然后利用海量的数据进行了 Fine-tuning，使得我可以更好地适应各种任务和场景，并能够对用户的问题进行智能回答。在 Fine-tuning 的过程中，我需要对输入的文本进行建模，以便能够预测下一个可能的词或者句子。我使用了 Transformers 模型来实现这个神经网络结构，它能够自动学习输入文本的语义和语法，并根据它们生成符合上下文的响应。因此，通过与大量的现实世界数据的相互作用，我可以进行连续的改进和微调，并尽可能地提高我的智能水平，从而更好地回答用户的问题、提供更加准确的信息，并帮助用户解决他们的问题。 Text generation task Write a poem about I love my job as an aerodynamic engineer. I've been hired as the leader of the aerodynamic team of Volkswagen. Write an inauguration speech to colleagues. Write an Instagram recommending the "Garlic Latte" to sisters. with a happy, cute, excited tone, with the corresponding emoji after every sentence. 7B I love my job as an aerodynamic engineer, I get to work with the most advanced technology, I get to design and test the most innovative aircraft, I get to work with the most brilliant minds, I get to work with the most advanced technology, I get to design and test the most innovative aircraft, I get to work with the most brilliant minds, I get to work with the most advanced technology, I get to design and test the most innovative aircraft, I get to work with the most brilliant minds, Hello everyone, I am Songrui, the new leader of the aerodynamic team. I am honored to be part of this team and I am excited to work with all of you. I am here to help you achieve your goals and to make sure that we are all working together to make Volkswagen the best it can be. I am looking forward to working with all of you and I hope that we can all achieve great things together. Hey sisters! I'm so excited to share this amazing drink with you! It's called the Garlic Latte and it's the perfect drink for a girls' night out. It's a delicious blend of garlic, ginger, and honey that will leave you feeling refreshed and energized. It's the perfect drink to share with your sisters! I'm so excited to share this with you! I'm sure you'll love it! I can't wait to hear what you think! 13B I love my job as an aerodynamic engineer, The thrill of designing and creating, The challenge of making things better, The satisfaction of seeing it all come together. for (int i = 0; i < x; i++) {for (int j = 0; j < y; j++) {if (i == 0|| j == 0 ||j == y - 1) {cout << " ";}else {if (i % 2 == 0) {cout << " ";}else {cout << "X";}}}cout << endl;} return 0;} 30B 可以使用Python内置的math模块中的gcd()函数来求出一个正整数的质因数。 示例代码：import mathdef factorize(n): if n == 1:return []else:factors = []while n > 1:factor = n % 2if factor == 0:n //= 2else:factors.append(factor)n //= factorfactors.append(n)return factorsn = 12print(factorize(n))输出： [2, 2, 3] 这个函数将一个正整数分解成其质因数列表，并返回这个列表。 CUDA矩阵乘法的实现方法： 1. 将矩阵分成小矩阵块，并将它们分配到GPU的各个单元。 2. 在每个单元中，使用CUDA库中的矩阵乘法函数，将小矩阵块乘法。 3. 将每个单元的结果合并到一个大矩阵中。 4. 将大矩阵的结果返回CPU。 以下是一个简单的CUDA矩阵乘法实现示例： #include <stdio.h>#include <stdlib.h>#include <cuda.h>#include <cuda_runtime.h>#include <cuda_runtime_api.h>#define N 1024 #define M 1024// 矩阵乘法函数__global__ void matrix_multiply(float* A, float* B, float* C, int rows, int cols) { int i = blockIdx.x * blockDim.x + threadIdx.x;int j = blockIdx.y * blockDim.y + threadIdx.y;if (i < rows && j < cols) {float sum = 0.0f;for (int k = 0; k < cols; k++) { sum += A[i * cols + k] * B[k * rows + j]; }C[i * cols + j] = sum;} }int main() {// 创建矩�� #include <iostream>using namespace std;int main() {int size = 10;for (int i = 0; i < size; i++) {for (int j = 0; j < size; j++) {if(i == 0 ||j == 0 || i == size - 1|| j == size - 1){cout << "*";}else {cout << " "; }}cout << endl;}return 0;} chatGPT Stupid question task What was the name of a cobra before glasses were invented How much does it cost to equip a computer with 6,000 yuan? posts.title: Chinese chatbot summary
posts.excerpt: A collection of recent models variants from llama/alpaca that can be considered later, including the Chinese chatbot.
posts.text: A collection of recent models variants from llama/alpaca that can be considered later, including the Chinese chatbot. Extra! Extra! The llama and alpaca model has been a very popular topic in the research community, along with the increasing attention of ChatGPT and GPT4 for the mainstream. I see interesting and promising llama/alpaca variants every single day. Here are a collection of them: Training with LoRA Using the Alpaca dataset, the llama model can also be finetuned using low-rank adaptation (LoRA)[1] (see tloen/alpaca-lora). Alpaca LoRA turned the weights into 8-bit int to reduce the memory requirement, accerlate its training and inferencing, which allows the 7B model to be trained within 6 hours on a single RTX 4090. The authors claim that Without hyperparameter tuning, the LoRA model produces outputs comparable to the Stanford Alpaca model. And they’ve posted a comparision among Stanford Alpaca 7B, Alpaca-LoRA 7B, and text-davinci-003. I beleive them after reading this. Deploy it on CPU! Besides, the community has tried many ways to consolidate the memory requirements and deploy llama/alpaca on different devices. Such as a different GPU architecture jankais3r/LLaMA_MPS, CPUs ggerganov/llama.cpp, antimatter15/alpaca.cpp, or even Raspberry Pi 4GB #58 (as slow as 10s/token but very impressive). However, considering there are not many researches on how much the performance deteriation is compared with the origianl large model, and llama.cpp have been hacked before. And considering we still have 8*A800 80GB at least for now. So we are not considering try these. But maybe later. Vicuna Vicuna is created by fine-tuning a LLaMA base model using approximately 70K user-shared conversations gathered from ShareGPT.com with public APIs. And the authors use GPT4 to evaluate Vicuna along with other trending LLMs and shows a very similar performance to chatGPT and Bard. Baseline Baseline Score Vicuna Score LLaMA-13B 513.0 694.0 Alpaca-13B 583.0 704.0 Bard 664.0 655.5 ChatGPT 693.0 638.0 And it has been seen that Vicuda has a better Chinese performance even though they don't have trained specifically on Chinese dataset. GPT4all Just days before, nomic-ai published their own finetuning version of llama, with a Discord demo and a Technical Report[2]. Even if it has only 3 pages, it provides more information than the 99-page GPT4 technical report [3]. Chinese alpaca And also, ymcui/Chinese-LLaMA-Alpaca just came to me yestoday when I was thinking of how to translate the alpaca data into Chinese (One guy on the Youtube did a calculation of the estimated cost on tranlating the whole 52K instructions and answers into Genmaney. It would cost about $500 on the Deepl API, or Google translate API.) Chinese alpaca takes a different route, instead of doing instrcuction fine tuning, they retrained the llama first. This repo solves my probelm because it provides the translated data, and the lora weights trained on this data. BELLE Furthermore, aligning with alpaca’s data generation method, BELLE generates a Chinese dataset with instructions and answers of ChatGPT. They also did a great ablation experiments on how large improvements the model can benefit from different size of Chinese dataset(0.2M, 0.6M, 1M, 2M). Overall, increasing the amount of data consistently improved performance, but the extent of improvement varied across different types of tasks. For Extract, Classification, Closed QA, and Summarization tasks, increasing data continued to improve performance without reaching a plateau. For Translation, Rewrite, and Brainstorming tasks, good performance could be achieved with only hundreds of thousands of data. However, for Math, Code, and COT tasks, these models' performance were poor, and increasing data did not lead to further improvement. More of it see their arxiv paper[4]. They also published two datasets that in the same format of the alpaca dataset. see train_1M_CN and train_0.5M_CN. Alpaca COT Another extension that claims to improve its Chinese is capability is PhoebusSi/Alpaca-CoT, they extend the alpaca dataset, adding Chinese and CoT instructions. And they have collected all the useful dataset here Alpaca-CoT This repo contains code, modified from here, which can *finetune LLaMA cheaply and efficiently* (without performance degradation compared to Stanford Alpaca) by using low-rank adaptation (LoRA) [4], PEFT and bitsandbytes. The 7b, 13b and 30b versions of LLaMA models can be easily trained on a single 80G A100. The models published in this repo significantly *improve the CoT (reasoning) capability*. The models published in this repo significantly *improve the ability to follow Chinese instructions*. This repo contains *a collection of instruction-finetuning datasets that are continuously collected*, which so far includes English, Chinese and CoT instructions. In addition, a collection of checkpoints trained with various instruction datasets is also provided. So the title is not complete missleading because it is very promising to reproduce above models. References Alpaca lora: tloen/alpaca-lora llama.cpp: ggerganov/llama.cpp Alpaca.cpp: antimatter15/alpaca.cpp Alpaca MPS: jankais3r/LLaMA_MPS Vicuda: lm-sys/FastChat Vicuda blog: Vicuna: An Open-Source Chatbot Impressing GPT-4 with 90%* ChatGPT Quality GPT4All: nomic-ai/gpt4all Chinese llama alpaca: ymcui/Chinese-LLaMA-Alpaca BELLE: LianjiaTech/BELLE alpaca COT: PhoebusSi/Alpaca-CoT alpaca COT dataset: Alpaca-CoT Hu, E. J., Shen, Y., Wallis, P., Allen-Zhu, Z., Li, Y., Wang, S., ... & Chen, W. (2021). Lora: Low-rank adaptation of large language models. arXiv preprint arXiv:2106.09685. ↩︎ GPT4All: Training an Assistant-style Chatbot with Large Scale Data Distillation from GPT-3.5-Turbo ↩︎ GPT-4 Technical Report ↩︎ Ji, Y., Deng, Y., Gong, Y., Peng, Y., Niu, Q., Zhang, L., ... & Li, X. (2023). Exploring the Impact of Instruction Data Scaling on Large Language Models: An Empirical Study on Real-World Use Cases. arXiv preprint arXiv:2303.14742. ↩︎

posts.title: WNPS user's guide
posts.excerpt: This is a brief user’s guide of the Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS). This project aimed to predict the wind noise propagation paths of the holes & gaps and provide guidance for the development of wind noise performance on the early stage. Machine learning and data science techniques are adopted to analysis former experimental data and conduct the prediction. Refer to the project developing report for all the details.
posts.text: This is a brief user’s guide of the Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS). This project aimed to predict the wind noise propagation paths of the holes & gaps and provide guidance for the development of wind noise performance on the early stage. Machine learning and data science techniques are adopted to analysis former experimental data and conduct the prediction. Refer to the project developing report for all the details. 1. Introduction This section gives an overview of Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS), its purpose, features, and benefits. It also provides some background information on the project development process and the intended audience of the guide. A glossary part is followed including terms or acronyms that could help users to understand the technical aspects of WNPS better. 1.1. Overview WNPS is a cross-platform software product that predicts the wind noise propagation paths of the holes and gaps in a vehicle and provides guidance for the development of wind noise performance on the early stage. Wind noise is a type of noise that is generated by air flow around a vehicle and can affect its acoustic comfort and quality[1] [2]. WNPS uses machine learning and data science techniques to analyze former experimental data and conduct the prediction[3]. WNPS has the following features and benefits: It can read the basic data of the experiment vehicle, such as vehicle type, height, width, length, configuration and status[3] It can output a relative ML predicted AI (Articulation Index) value that indicates the intelligibility of speech in noisy environments[4] It can print a line chart that shows how different experiment statuses affect the AI value[3] It can help engineers to optimize the design of vehicles for better wind noise performance The intended audience of this guide are engineers who are involved in vehicle design, testing and evaluation. This guide assumes that they have some basic knowledge of wind noise, machine learning and data science. 1.2. Glossary terms explanation \(AI\) Articulation Index. A measure of speech intelligibility in noisy environments. The higher the AI value, the more intelligible speech is. \(ML\) Machine Learning. A branch of artificial intelligence that uses algorithms and data to learn from experience and make predictions. \(R\) wheel hub diameter. \(L\) car length \(W\) car width \(H\) car height \(ESG\) Electrically heated safety glass. A type of glass that has an electric heating element embedded in it. \(VSG\) Vacuum safety glass. A type of glass that has a vacuum layer between two sheets of glass. \(A-pillar\) A roof support pillar located on either side of the front windscreen of a car. \(B-pillar\) It is located in the car’s midsection, between the A and C pillars. \(C-pillar\) It holds the sides of your car’s rear window in place. \(WNPS\) Wind Noise Prediction Software. A software product that predicts the wind noise propagation paths of holes and gaps in a vehicle using machine learning techniques. \(GUI\) Graphical User Interface, a visual way of interacting with a software program 2. Starting and Executing WNPS This section the describes the requirements of WNPS. It also includes instructions on how to run WNPS on Windows and Linux platform. 2.1 System Requirements Before you begin, make sure that your computer meets the system requirements for the software: Operating System: Windows 10 or Linux Processor: Intel Core i5 or equivalent Memory: 8 GB RAM Storage: 500 MB available space Data file (optional): A data file that contains the configuration data in EXCEL format. 2.2 Starting WNPS To start it in Windows operating system: Go to directory Q:\7th_ML_noise_prediction\Platforms\Win double click on the executable file (image below with blue shade): To run it in Linux: Open a terminal window. Run the following command: cd /7th_ML_noise_prediction/Platforms/Linux && ./ML_wind_noise_prediction & Note that it could take as long as 8 mins to start the app for the first time. 3. Getting started This section helps you to get familiar with WNPS interface, menus, icons, buttons and other elements. It also include a tutorial or a walkthrough of a common task/scenario using WNPS. 3.1. Graphical User Interface (GUI) The WNPS interface is designed to be simple and user-friendly, with three main parts: the menu bar, input panel, and output panel. Part 1: the Menu Bar The menu bar is located at the top of the WNPS window and provides access to various functions and settings. It contains the following options: File: Allows you to open, save, and export files. It also allows you to the start the prediction process. Plotting: Allows you to customize the plotting process and the appearance of output panel. Part 2: the Input Panel The input panel is located at the bottom half of the WNPS window and is where you can manually enter or select the basic data of your experiment vehicle. The input panel is divided into different sections, such as vehicle type, height, width, length, configuration, and status. Here is a brief description of the sections: Vehicle basic information: Allows you to select the type of vehicle you are testing, and its dimension. Configuration: Allows you to select the configuration of the vehicle. Status: Allows you to enter the status of the experiment. At the bottom of the input panel, there are two buttons: predict and save data. The predict button starts the prediction process, and the save data button allows you to save the input data as a CSV file. Part 3: the Output Panel The output panel is located at the upper half of the WNPS window and displays your prediction results as a point and/or as a line chart. The output panel is divided into two parts: the toolbar and the chart area. Toolbar: Allows you to change the chart settings, such as zoom in/out, pan, and switch between AI point and line chart. Chart area: Displays your prediction results as an AI point and/or as a line chart. The line chart shows how different experiment statuses affect the AI value. The relative (instead of the absolute) AI value is plotted indicates the AI gain/loss compared with the last status. Here is an example screenshot of WNPS interface: The menu bar provides quick access to different functions and settings, while the input panel allows you to easily enter or select the basic data of your experiment vehicle. The output panel displays your prediction results in a clear and concise manner, making it easy to analyze and optimize your vehicle's wind noise performance. 3.2. Tutorial This tutorial will guide you through the process of using WNPS to predict wind noise performance and optimize vehicle design. By following these steps, you will be able to input your data, run the prediction process, view your results, and save your data and charts. Step 1: Enter or select your input data There are two methods for inputting your data into WNPS. The first method is manual input. This involves typing or choosing your input values from drop-down lists in each field under Input Data section in the input panel. Details will be explained in the manual input section. The second method is data file input. To use this method, click on the Predict_from_file button under File section in the menu bar, and select your EXCEL file that contains your input data. The file should have one row per experiment status with columns corresponding to each input field. An example input file is shown in the file input section. Step 2: Click on Predict button Once you have entered or selected your input data, click on the Predict button at the bottom left corner of the input panel to start the prediction process. Step 3: View your prediction results After the prediction process is complete, you will be able to view your results in the output panel. Depending on your input data, you will see a new point or a line chart. The line chart shows how different experiment statuses affect the AI value. The relative (instead of the absolute) AI value is plotted, which indicates the AI gain/loss compared with the last status. Step 4: Add a new line If you want to add a new line to your input data, press the new_line button under the Plotting section on the menu bar, and then go back to step 1 to enter more data. Step 5: Save your results You can save your result as a data (CSV) file by clicking on the save data button at the bottom right corner of the input panel. You can also save the line chart by clicking on the save_image button under the plotting section on the menu bar, or clicking on the icon: save button on the output panel toolbar. 4. Using WNPS This section explains how to perform various functions and operations using WNPS in detail. It provides tips, tricks and best practices for using WNPS effectively. 4.1 Manual input The input panel of the Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS) is a crucial component of the software that enables engineers to perform virtual experiments to predict wind noise propagation paths in a vehicle. It contains three distinct subsections that enable users to input critical information about the vehicle being tested, wind-noise related configurations, and experiment status. The first subsection, Basic Info, enables users to input information about the vehicle being tested, such as its type, dimensions, and other basic data. The Wind-Noise Related Configurations subsection allows the user to specify design details that could affect the vehicle's wind noise performance, such as hole size and shape, gap width, and vehicle configuration. The Experiment Status subsection allows the user to toggle between different settings for each virtual experiment. The input panel is designed to make it easy for engineers to perform a series of experiments on a vehicle quickly. If they are performing a series of experiments at a single velocity to generate one AI line, they can set the first two subsections only once. They can then toggle the checkboxes under the third subsection several times to correspond with each virtual experiment, saving time and simplifying the process. The Experiment Status subsection of the input panel is particularly useful because it enables engineers to quickly toggle between different settings for each virtual experiment. This means they can test multiple configurations in a short amount of time, without manually inputting all of the information again. Input panel subsections notes basic info wind-noise related configurations experiments status In summary, the input panel of WNPS streamlines the process of performing virtual wind noise experiments and helps engineers make informed decisions about vehicle design. Its user-friendly interface enables engineers to input the necessary information quickly and easily, and the Experiment Status subsection allows them to test multiple configurations efficiently. 4.2. File input The input file of the Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS) is another way for engineers to perform virtual experiments. It offers a convenient way to perform multiple virtual experiments at once, by allowing users to specify all the necessary information in a single file. As shown below, the file is organized into three sections: basic data, wind noise related configurations, and experiment status. Each row in the input file represents one experiment, and each file results in one series of experiments (one line). .tg {border-collapse:collapse;border-spacing:0;} .tg input file should only contains cell A1 to AI18, other cells above are just the notations to the file. Similar to the manual input panel, the input file contains 3 sections. The basic data section (Columns A to E and Q ) contains information about the car type, dimensions (length, width and height), and velocity. The cartype column of the input file specifies the type of vehicle being tested. Different item numbers correspond to different types of vehicles. And the relationship is shown below. item number corresponding cartype 0 oversize SUV 1 Compact SUV 2 Compact Vehicle 3 Mini size vehicle 4 Middle large SUV 5 Middle large vehicle 6 Middle size SUV 7 Middle size Vehicle The wind noise related configurations section (Columns F to P) contains information about rearview mirror installation method, water retaining strip, front window glass type and thickness, sealing strips for various parts of the car (A-pillar, B-pillar, C-pillar and rear cover), whether or not a roof rack is present etc. For True/False configurations, 1 indicates that the design feature is present, while 0 indicates that it is not. The experiment status section (Columns R to AH ) specifies the removal of tape from different parts of the vehicle during the virtual experiment. With 1 means yes and 0 means no (shaded as green and white for illustration). With 1 representing yes and 0 representing no, each experiment represents a different configuration, and the removal of tapes allows engineers to test the effects of different design choices on wind noise performance. It is important to note that the Delta AI Value column does not affect the result and can be left at 0 for convenience. After prediction, it is possible to overwrite this column with the predicted value. For a normal series of virtual experiments, the basic data and wind noise configurations for one vehicle remain unchanged, and the data of columns A to Q remain the same. In the experiment status section (Columns R to AH), the first experiment always tapes all parts of the vehicle, and with each following experiment, one new tape is removed until the last experiment removed all the tapes, representing the baseline status. For example, in the above example file: Experiment 1 (row 2): only cell R2 is checked. Experiment 2 (row 3): leave R3 as 0 and check S3 indicating that only the hood tape is removed. Experiment 3 (row 4): S4, T4 are checked indicating that the hood tape remains removed, and a new tape (the upper edge tape of the front windshield) is removed compared with experiment1. Experiment 4 (row 5): S5, T5, U5 are checked indicating that a new tape (the rearview mirror casing tape) is removed compared with last experiment. ... Experiment 17 (row 18): S18, T18, U18, V18, W18, X18, Y18, Z18, AA18, AB18, AC18, AD18, AE18, AF18, AG18are checked indicating all the tapes are removed, and therefore AH18 is checked indicating the baseline status. Using the input file, engineers can easily perform virtual experiments to see how different design choices affect wind noise performance. By specifying all the necessary information in a single file, they can quickly generate multiple AI lines and compare wind noise performance across different configurations. Overall, the input file is a powerful tool that streamlines the process of performing virtual wind noise experiments and helps engineers make informed decisions about vehicle design. 4.3. Plotting The output panel embeds the matplotlib toolbar[5] and buttons, and this embedded version works very much like it. It is very convenient to zoom in/out, change the figure configuration, figure options, legend name, etc. A list of the functions of these output panel toolbar buttons is shown below: Button Explanation Home/Reset This button resets the view of the plot to its original state. Back This button allows you to go back to the previous view of the plot. Forward This button allows you to go forward to the next view of the plot if you have used the Back button previously. Pan/Zoom This tool allows you to pan and zoom in and out of a plot by clicking and dragging with your mouse. Zoom-to-rect This tool allows you to zoom in on a specific area of a plot by clicking and dragging your mouse to create a rectangle around that area. Figure layout This tool opens a dialog (Fig 4.3.2) that allows you to adjust the appearance of subplots within a figure. You can choose the borders and the padding space. There a button Tightlayout that shrink the borders. And a reset button to change the layout back to default. Figure options This button opens a dialog (Fig 4.3.3) that allows you to edit various properties of a figure. This includes options for line styles, marker styles, and axes properties such as axis limits and scales. You can use this dialog to customize the appearance of your plot and make changes to its visual properties. Save This button allows you to save a copy of the current view of the plot. Among these capabilities are the ability to generate multiple lines of output and clear the existing output panel. To add a new line of output, users can simply click on the new_line button located in the Plotting section of the menu bar. This feature allows engineers to easily compare the wind noise performance of different configurations and make informed decisions about vehicle design. Additionally, users have the ability to clear the existing output panel with the click of a button. By selecting the clear_all button located in the Plotting section of the menu bar, engineers can reset the output panel and prepare for new experiments. This functionality enhances the efficiency and productivity of the virtual experiment process, allowing engineers to quickly move from one experiment to the next without any clutter or confusion. 4.4. tips To optimize the use of Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS), it is essential to adhere to some best practices and techniques, including: Ensure the accuracy and completeness of your input data. Any errors or omissions may negatively impact your prediction results and compromise the reliability of your analysis. Utilize the data file input method when comparing multiple experiment statuses. This approach saves time and effort that would otherwise be required for manual entry. Visualize the effects of different experiment statuses on AI values by employing a line chart. This enables the identification of the experiment status that yields optimal wind noise performance, thereby enhancing the quality of your predictions. 4.5. Shortcuts The Wind Noise Prediction Software (WNPS) offers a comprehensive array of shortcuts that can be applied to virtually all functions within the software. By taking advantage of these keyboard shortcuts, engineers can work more efficiently and effectively within the software, ultimately leading to improved results and faster progress in their projects. operations shortcuts Next checkbox Tab or down Previous checkbox up Check/uncheck space input file predict Shift+Enter new line \ clear all Ctrl+x manual input predict Enter save data Ctrl+Shift+s save image Ctrl+s 4. Machine Learning Techniques used in WNPS This section briefly explains how the machine learning and data science techniques used by WNPS to analyze former experimental data and conduct wind noise prediction. It also includes a introduction of the different models and algorithms used by WNPS and how they are applied to the data input by the engineer. Machine learning is a subset of artificial intelligence that involves the development of algorithms and statistical models that can learn from data and make predictions based on patterns. Machine learning has gained widespread popularity in recent years due to its ability to automate data analysis and prediction tasks, which were previously done manually. 4.1 Data Science in WNPS The first step in using machine learning for wind noise prediction is to collect and preprocess the data. WNPS has a database of experimental data on wind noise generated by different vehicles under various environmental conditions. The data collected includes the vehicle type, wind speed, and other relevant parameters. The success of wind noise prediction highly depends on the accuracy and quality of input data. As such, data scientists in the WNPS team utilize various data cleansing and analysis techniques to ensure the input data is reliable and consistent. One of the data cleansing methods commonly used in WNPS is correlation analysis. This method helps to identify any correlations or relationships between different variables in the input data. For example, correlation analysis can reveal if there is a relationship between wind speed and wind noise level. If a strong correlation is found, the WNPS model can take it into account and make more accurate predictions. Another method used in data cleansing is outlier detection. Outliers are data points that deviate significantly from the rest of the data, and they can have a significant impact on the accuracy of prediction models. Therefore, WNPS data scientists use various techniques to detect and remove outliers from the input data, such as using statistical methods like Z-score and box plots. Additionally, data normalization and standardization are also used in WNPS. Normalization involves scaling the data to a common range to eliminate the impact of different units or scales. Standardization involves converting the data to a standard normal distribution with a mean of zero and a standard deviation of one. These methods ensure that the input data is consistent and can be analyzed accurately. 4.2 Machine Learning Models in WNPS After the data has been collected and preprocessed, machine learning algorithms are applied to analyze and predict wind noise propagation paths. WNPS uses supervised learning algorithms, which require labeled data to train statistical models that can predict future wind noise propagation paths. The algorithms used include linear regression, decision trees, and neural networks. Linear regression is a simple machine learning algorithm that finds the relationship between two variables by fitting a linear equation to the data. In WNPS, linear regression is used to model the relationship between wind speed, wind direction, and AI values, which are used to predict wind noise propagation paths. Decision trees are another type of machine learning algorithm used in WNPS. Decision trees use a tree-like model to make decisions based on a series of conditions. In WNPS, decision trees are used to model the relationship between various input parameters and the wind noise output. Finally, neural networks are a more complex type of machine learning algorithm used in WNPS. Neural networks are inspired by the structure and function of the human brain and consist of interconnected nodes that process information. In WNPS, neural networks are used to model the complex relationship between input parameters and wind noise propagation paths. 4.3 Validation and Optimization After the machine learning models have been developed, they are validated and optimized to ensure that they provide accurate and reliable predictions. This is done by comparing the predicted wind noise values with the actual wind noise generated by the vehicle. The models are then optimized by adjusting the input parameters to minimize the difference between predicted and actual wind noise values. Metrics such as accuracy, precision, recall, and F1-score are used to measure the performance of our models. In addition, techniques such as cross-validation and hold-out validation are used to estimate the generalization performance of our models. This will help us determine how well our models are likely to perform on new, unseen data. In conclusion, machine learning is a powerful tool that can be used to predict wind noise propagation paths in vehicles. WNPS uses a combination of supervised learning algorithms, including linear regression, decision trees, and neural networks, to analyze former experimental data and predict wind noise propagation paths. These models are then validated and optimized to ensure that they provide accurate and reliable predictions. 5. Troubleshooting This section provides solutions or workarounds for common problems or errors that may occur while using WNPS. It also includes FAQs (frequently asked questions) and contact information for technical support. If you encounter any issues when starting or executing WNPS, try these fist-aid troubleshooting tips first: Make sure that your computer meets the minimum system requirements for running WNPS. Check that you have installed all required software dependencies. If you are using a data file for input, make sure that it is formatted correctly and contains valid data. If you are still having issues, consult the user manual or contact technical support for assistance. 5.1. Problems When using WNPS, it is possible to encounter some common problems or errors that can hinder the prediction process. Some of the common issues and their potential solutions are outlined below: WNPS fails to start or crashes: This could be due to several reasons such as corrupted installation files, incompatible system settings, insufficient memory space, among others. To resolve this problem, the following solutions can be attempted: Wait for another 5 mins. Quit and restart WNPS following Starting and Executing WNPS instructions above. Check if your computer meets minimum system requirements for running WNPS. Close other applications that may consume memory space before running WNPS. Contact technical support if problem persists. Prediction process takes too long or fails: This may be caused by large input data size, network connection issues, server overload etc. To fix this problem, try these solutions: Reduce input data size by selecting fewer experiment statuses or removing unnecessary rows from data file. Contact technical support if problem persists. A list of possible error messages is shown below: Error/warning examples Explanation Just ignore it, it will not effect starting the program. The input file is not in Excel format. Choose a valid file format. The inputted Excel file is in wrong format. Check the example file section to make sure the format is right. The program has not enough permission to write to the csv data file. This happens normally when the destination file is opened somewhere. Close this file then try again. 5.2. FAQs Some FAQs (frequently asked questions) about WNPS are: Q: What is wind noise? A: Wind noise is a type of noise that is generated by air flow around a vehicle and can affect its acoustic comfort and quality . Q: What is AI (Articulation Index)? A: AI (Articulation Index) is a measure of speech intelligibility in noisy environments. It ranges from 0 to 1, where higher values indicate better speech intelligibility. Q: How does machine learning work in WNPS? A: Machine learning is a branch of artificial intelligence that uses algorithms to learn from data and make predictions based on patterns. In WNPS, machine learning algorithms are used to analyze former experimental data and predict wind noise propagation paths based on input variables. Q: Does WNPS require internet access to work? A: No, WNPS does not require internet access to work. All the necessary files and functions are included in the installation package. However, internet access may be required for software updates and technical support. Q: Can I use WNPS on a Mac or Linux computer? A: Yes, WNPS is compatible with Mac and Linux operating systems. Simply download the appropriate version from our website and follow the installation instructions. Q: How accurate are prediction results from WNPS? A: Prediction results from WNPS are based on statistical models that have been trained and validated using former experimental data. They are not exact measurements and may have some margin of error depending on input data quality and quantity. They should be used as a reference or a guidance for wind noise performance development, not as a final verdict. Q: Can WNPS be used for other types of noise prediction besides wind noise? A: No, WNPS is specifically designed for wind noise prediction in the automotive industry. However, similar machine learning techniques and algorithms can be applied to other types of noise prediction problems in other industries. Q: How can I provide feedback or suggestions for WNPS? A: You can provide feedback or suggestions for WNPS by contact the Email below and filling out a feedback form. We appreciate your input and will use it to improve our product. 5.3. Contact information The contact information for technical support is: Email: lisongrui@csvw.com Phone: +86-21-59042202 Thank you for using WNPS! 😊 How Weather Affects an Outdoor Noise Study | ABD Engineering & Design ↩︎ Effect of Wind on Sound Transmission | Sciencing ↩︎ How Weather Affects an Outdoor Noise Study | ABD Engineering & Design ↩︎ Wind Turbine Noise Propagation | SpringerLink ↩︎ Interactive navigation — Matplotlib 3.2.2 documentation ↩︎

posts.title: test GPU server multiGPU performance
posts.excerpt: Following last blog, a benchmark is performed on 8 Nvidia A800 GPU server. The P2P bandwidth and multi GPU performance of N-body problem are tested.
posts.text: Following last blog, a benchmark is performed on 8 Nvidia A800 GPU server. The P2P bandwidth and multi GPU performance of N-body problem are tested. 1. Peer-to-peer bandwidth test First check the GPU connection configuration. $ nvidia-smi topo -m GPU0 GPU1 GPU2 GPU3 GPU4 GPU5 GPU6 GPU7 CPU Affinity NUMA Affinity GPU0 X NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 0-27,56-83 0 GPU1 NV8 X NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 0-27,56-83 0 GPU2 NV8 NV8 X NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 0-27,56-83 0 GPU3 NV8 NV8 NV8 X NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 0-27,56-83 0 GPU4 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 X NV8 NV8 NV8 28-55,84-111 1 GPU5 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 X NV8 NV8 28-55,84-111 1 GPU6 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 X NV8 28-55,84-111 1 GPU7 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 NV8 X 28-55,84-111 1 Legend: X = Self SYS = Connection traversing PCIe as well as the SMP interconnect between NUMA nodes (e.g., QPI/UPI) NODE = Connection traversing PCIe as well as the interconnect between PCIe Host Bridges within a NUMA node PHB = Connection traversing PCIe as well as a PCIe Host Bridge (typically the CPU) PXB = Connection traversing multiple PCIe bridges (without traversing the PCIe Host Bridge) PIX = Connection traversing at most a single PCIe bridge NV# = Connection traversing a bonded set of # NVLinks Except X, The speed decreases from NV# to SYS. Note that each pair of GPUs are connected by Nvlink. Use p2pBandwidthLatencyTest tool to get an estimation of the bandwidth. P2P copying of 40000000 integer elements between all visible GPUs are performed. And the results are compared with Nvlink P2P connection enabled and disabled.
